description: From Middle English disavauntage, from Old French desavantage.

entries.meaning: A weakness or undesirable characteristic; a con.
examples: The disadvantage to owning a food processor is that you have to store it somewhere.
My height is a disadvantage for reaching high shelves.
They would throw a construction on his conduct, to his disadvantage before the public.

verbs.description: disadvantage (third-person singular simple present disadvantages, present participle disadvantaging, simple past and past participle disadvantaged)

examples: They fear it might disadvantage honest participants to allow automated entries.
